VLIB Function Reference

Recursive IIR Filter: Vertical, First-Order

Introduction and Use Cases

A variety of image processing algorithms can be implemented through recursive IIR filters, including smoothing and gradient/edge computations. These methods can be preferred over FIR (convolutional) filters for their computational efficiency

Specification

Function

This function implements the 1st order vertical IIR filter.

Variants

This functionality is available in two variants: 8-bit and 16-bit

Inputs


    Parameter          Description                      8-bit            16-bit
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    *out               Filter output image             (UQ8.0)          (SQ15.0)
    *in                Input luma image                (UQ8.0)          (SQ15.0)
     width             Input Width                     (SQ31.0)         (SQ31.0)
     height            Image Height                    (SQ31.0)         (SQ31.0)
     weight            Filter coefficient              (SQ15.0)         (SQ15.0)
     boundaryTop       Array of top-boundary values    (UQ8.0)          (SQ15.0)
     boundaryBottom    Array of bottom-boundary values (UQ8.0)          (SQ15.0)
     scratch           Scratch buffer                  (UQ8.0)          (SQ15.0)

Outputs

    Returns VLIB Error Status

Method

For each pixel, computation uses the following equation: 
    output(x,y) = 0.5 x (output_TB(x,y) + output_BT(x,y))
In the equation above, output_TB is the causal filter component, processing pixels from top to bottom, and output_BT is the anti-causal component, processing pixels bottom to top. These are defined in the following equations: 
    output_TB(x,y) = weight x input(x,y) + (1-weight) x output_TB(x, y-1)
    output_BT(x,y) = weight x input(x,y) + (1-weight) x output_BT(x, y+1)
In both the 8-bit and 16-bit variants, the intermediate IIR results are computed at 16-bit precision. In the 8-bit variant, the output is cast to 8-bits. The top- and bottom-boundary values can be passed via array pointers boundaryTop and boundaryBottom. If these pointers are NULL, boundary image pixel values will be used as initial conditions.

APIS

  • VLIB_recursiveFilterVert1stOrder
  • VLIB_recursiveFilterVert1stOrderS16

Notes

  • The scratch buffer must be at least 4 x height bytes (for 8-bit variant) or 8 x height bytes(for 16-bit variant).
  • The image width and height needs to be a multiple of 4.
  • The input and output image buffers need to be double-word aligned.

References

  1. Fast Algorithms for Low-Level Vision by R. Deriche, PAMI (12), 1, 1990
